t: Proverbs 27
Do*pn not boast about tomorrow, for*ld you do not know what a day may bring.
Let*pn someone else praise you, and not your own mouth; an*ld outsider, and not your own lips.
Stone*pn is heavy and sand a burden, but*ld a fool’s provocation is heavier than both.
Anger*pn is cruel and fury overwhelming, but*ld who can stand before jealousy?
Better*pn is open rebuke than*ld hidden love.
Wounds*pn from a friend can be trusted, but*ld an enemy multiplies kisses.
One*pn who is full loathes honey from the comb, but*ld to the hungry even what is bitter tastes sweet.
Like*pn a bird that flees its nest is*ld anyone who flees from home.
Perfume*pn and incense bring joy to the heart, and*ld the pleasantness of a friend springs*ld from their heartfelt advice.
Do*pn not forsake your friend or a friend of your family, and*ld do not go to your relative’s house when disaster strikes you— better*ld a neighbor nearby than a relative far away.
Be*pn wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart; then*ld I can answer anyone who treats me with contempt.
The*pn prudent see danger and take refuge, but*ld the simple keep going and pay the penalty.
Take*pn the garment of one who puts up security for a stranger; hold*ld it in pledge if it is done for an outsider.
If*pn anyone loudly blesses their neighbor early in the morning, it*ld will be taken as a curse.
A*pn quarrelsome wife is like the dripping of*ld a leaky roof in a rainstorm;
restraining*ln her is like restraining the wind or*ld grasping oil with the hand.
As*pn iron sharpens iron, so*ld one person sharpens another.
The*pn one who guards a fig tree will eat its fruit, and*ld whoever protects their master will be honored.
As*pn water reflects the face, so*ld one’s life reflects the heart.
Death*pn and Destruction are never satisfied, and*ld neither are human eyes.
The*pn crucible for silver and the furnace for gold, but*ld people are tested by their praise.
Though*pn you grind a fool in a mortar, grinding*ld them like grain with a pestle, you*ld will not remove their folly from them.
Be*pn sure you know the condition of your flocks, give*ld careful attention to your herds;
for*ln riches do not endure forever, and*ld a crown is not secure for all generations.
When*ln the hay is removed and new growth appears and*ld the grass from the hills is gathered in,
the*ln lambs will provide you with clothing, and*ld the goats with the price of a field.
You*ln will have plenty of goats’ milk to feed your family and*ld to nourish your female servants.
